thread.title: Arsene Wenger won't be relishing Lincoln tie after Arsenal's uncomfortable night in Sutton - John Cross
thread.title_full: Arsene Wenger won't be relishing Lincoln tie after Arsenal's uncomfortable night in Sutton - John Cross - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Arsene Wenger won't be relishing Lincoln tie after Arsenal's uncomfortable night in Sutton - John Cross
text:
Arsene Wenger won't be relishing Lincoln tie after Arsenal's uncomfortable night in Sutton The Gunners beat the non-league outfit 2-0 but had some hairy moments at Gander Green Lane   Share   Comments By John Cross 22:44, 20 FEB 2017 Updated 22:57, 20 FEB 2017 Sport Opinion Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain blocks a shot on goal from Sutton's Bedsente Gomis (Photo: Getty)   Share   Comments Get Arsenal FC   They were cheered off at the final whistle as FA Cup heroes.
Never mind Sutton’s gallant adventure ended in glorious failure, this was a night that no-one at Gander Green Lane will ever forget.
Despite being 105 places below mighty Arsenal , Paul Doswell’s non-league giant killers did themselves proud and reminded us all just how special the FA Cup is. 
It was a brilliant David and Goliath battle and, even if Arsenal do go on to reach Wembley, this will go down as one of their toughest ties.
Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger sits on the bench during his side's victory over Sutton (Photo: REUTERS) Lucas Perez scored the opening goal in the FA Cup fifth round clash (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Theo Walcott scores his 100th Arsenal goal as Arsene Wenger's side dodge FA Cup banana skin It was never comfortable for Arsenal and Arsene Wenger even brought on superstar striker Alexis Sanchez as an insurance policy late on to see it out.
Lucas Perez and Theo Walcott scored in either half but the scoreline only told half the story as Arsenal struggled not just because of the plastic pitch but also because of Sutton’s wonderful spirit.
Sutton’s former Arsenal trainee Roarie Deacon, man-of-the-match despite the elite company, went as close as anyone for the Vanarama National League club.
Deacon smashed a 25-yard shot against the crossbar but, in truth, it was already 2-0 by then and Arsenal had eased off which was a dangerous thing to do.
Perez celebrates scoring his sides opening goal (Photo: PA) Theo Walcott scores Arsenal's second goal (Photo: Rex Features) Sutton never surrendered, they never gave up and Arsenal were pushed to the limit before finally securing a victory to set up a quarter final against another non-league opponent, Lincoln City.
Arsene Wenger will be praying that Lincoln do not give them as tough a game as Sutton but you can bet that he will not be relishing it, despite the tie being at the Emirates.
Wenger has won the FA Cup six times during 20 years at Arsenal but this was his first ever trip to a non-league club in the famous old competition.
Wenger spoke glowingly before kick-off, saying he always enjoyed going to smaller clubs but it turned into a nervous night with Arsenal always on a hiding to nothing.
The strike was the England forward's 100th goal for the club (Photo: REUTERS) Shkodran Mustafi in action with Sutton United's Kevin Amankwaah (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger admits Sutton were better than he expected them to be The Frenchman is under extreme pressure at the Emirates and defeat to Sutton would have been unforgivable and unthinkable.
However, Arsenal teetered on the plastic pitch, they struggled to make their Premier League quality count despite fielding seven full internationals in a mix and match of youngsters, first-teamers and fringe players,
Sutton were strong, physical and were not intimidated. But it took Arsenal 27 minutes to go ahead as Granit Xhaka spread the ball wide to Perez, the Spanish striker cut in and unleashed a low left footed shot.
Perez has been complaining about a lack of first team chances but he clearly had a point to prove and his low cross shot flew into the far corner.
Alexis Sanchez is grabbed by fans on the pitch after full time (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Sutton United fans invade the pitch at the full time whistle (Photo: Rex Features) That should have calmed nerves but Arsenal keeper David Ospina looked edgy and nervous, he looked uncomfortable and a poor clearance gifted a chance to Adam May but the Sutton midfielder fired tamely wide.
Arsenal came out for the second half and you expected them to exert their superiority and extra fitness. But that never really happened even after Walcott made it two after 55 minutes.
Nacho Monreal and Alex Iwobi combined on the left edge of the box and then Walcott fired in a cross from close range.
Hundreds of fans make it on to the pitch (Photo: AFP) Sutton's fans were celebrating their historic FA Cup run (Photo: REUTERS) But it was almost as if Sutton then decided they had nothing to lose, they relaxed and played their best football as Deacon smashed the woodwork and Jamie Collins headed over a big chance.
On came Sanchez but still Arsenal could not relax until the final whistle blew to end Sutton’s fairytale. Sadly, it also saw hundreds of fans run onto the pitch as the supporters baited each other in an unsavoury ending to the night.
But not even that should take the gloss off Sutton’s memorable FA Cup run and Arsenal will be grateful they did not become another giant killing victim.
poll loading Will Arsenal win the FA Cup this season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR YES NO   Arsenal FC Newsletter Follow @mirrorfootball Subscribe to our Arsenal FC   Comments Show more comments More On Theo Walcott Alexis Sanchez Arsene Wenger David Ospina FA Cup Lincoln City Football Club Premier League Arsenal FC
